content: In the following questions, I will provide you with a graph (given as an array of nodes and an array of edges), a starting point, and a target point. Please return the shortest path from the starting point to the target point in the following format: 1->2->3->4... Please note that your answer should only include the result in this format.(For each problem, you need to first present three related but not identical problems, along with a description of each problem and its solution. Finally, provide the answer to the original problem in the form of "Therefore, the final answer is: ".)

Related problem 1:
Description: Given the same graph, starting point, and destination, find the length of the shortest path from the starting point to the destination.
Solution: Use Breadth First Search (BFS) to traverse the graph starting from the starting point until you reach the destination. Keep track of the path length. Return the length of the shortest path.

Related problem 2:
Description: Given the same graph, starting point, and destination, determine if there exists a path from the starting point to the destination.
Solution: Utilize BFS to traverse the graph from the starting point. If the destination node is reached during traversal, return True indicating a path exists, otherwise return False.

Related problem 3:
Description: Given the same graph, starting point, find all possible paths from the starting point to all other nodes in the graph.
Solution: Implement Depth First Search (DFS) to explore all possible paths starting from the given starting point to all other nodes in the graph. Return all the paths found.

Therefore, the final answer is: 6->5->0->1->2.

Related problem 1:
Description: Given the same graph, starting point, and destination, find the length of the shortest path from the starting point to the destination.
Solution: Use Breadth First Search (BFS) to traverse the graph starting from the starting point until you reach the destination. Keep track of the path length. Return the length of the shortest path.

Related problem 2:
Description: Given the same graph, starting point, and destination, determine if there exists a path from the starting point to the destination.
Solution: Utilize BFS to traverse the graph from the starting point. If the destination node is reached during traversal, return True indicating a path exists, otherwise return False.

Related problem 3:
Description: Given the same graph, starting point, find all possible paths from the starting point to all other nodes in the graph.
Solution: Implement Depth First Search (DFS) to explore all possible paths starting from the given starting point to all other nodes in the graph. Return all the paths found.

Therefore, the final answer is: 6->0->1->2.
